Authors: Ming Tang, Chen Ren, Qin-Er Yang
Title:
Parasenecio chenopodifolius (Compositae-Senecioneae) is a
Synotis and conspecific with S. otophylla based on evidence from
morphology, cytology, and ITS/ETS sequence data
Abstract:
Observations on living plants and herbarium specimens have
convinced us that Synotis otophylla (Compositae-Senecioneae) from south
Xizang (Tibet), China, must be merged with the Himalayan Parasenecio
chenopodifolius. However, is the plant a Synotis or a Parasenecio? We
have examined floral micromorphological and cytological characters of P.
chenopodifolius, and performed molecular phylogenetic analyses based on
ITS and ETS sequence data. The anther collar of this taxon is
balusterform, and the endothecial tissue cell wall thickenings are
radial. These conform to the floral microcharacters of Synotis but
differ from those of Parasenecio, which has subcylindrical anther
collars, and polarized endothecial tissue cell wall thickenings.
Chromosomes counts indicate the taxon has 2n = 40, a number common in
Synotis; Parasenecio has 2n = 60. Our phylogenetic analyses based on
ITS/ETS sequences also place P. chenopodifolius in Synotis. We propose
the new combination S. chenopodifolia and synonymize S. otophylla.
